creditline: Gift of Richard L. Simmons in memory of Roberta Grodberg Simmons
inscription:
Inscription

at one corner, in black: [31]
object_name: Cloth, Cloth for woman's head covering or man's waist wrap, Woman's head covering, Sari
text: This cotton ikat fabric is from an unused stockpile of similar telia cloth - so-called because the traditional dyeing process involved treating the threads with sesame oil (tel). Produced in the southeast Indian coastal town of Chirala, telia cloth found a ready market in Hyderabad, the area's main trade center. The fabric, often decorated with white embroidery, made an attractive head covering for women. Men wore it plain as a waist wrap.
title: Cloth for woman's veil (Telia dupatta) or man's waist wrap (Telia lungi)
